childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1991-2003

You were born the year the Soviet Union collapsed and the World Wide Web went public. The Cold War ended before you could walk. Saddam Hussein became a household name while you were still in diapers. The defining geopolitical struggle of the twentieth century wrapped up just in time for you to inherit whatever came next.

Your childhood was the last gasp of analog culture. You probably had a landline, a VCR, and a Blockbuster membership card with your parents' name on it. Friday nights meant wandering aisles of videotapes, trying to agree on a movie. Returning them on time was a whole thing. Late fees were real consequences.

You were five when Princess Diana died. Seven when Clinton got impeached over a scandal you didn't understand. Nine during Y2K, which turned out to be nothing. Ten when 9/11 happened, old enough to remember the day clearly, young enough for it to reshape your entire childhood. The towers fell on a Tuesday. By Wednesday, American flags were everywhere. By the weekend, nothing felt the same.

Technology crept in gradually. Your family's first computer probably ran Windows 95 or 98. You remember AOL Instant Messenger, setting a clever away message, and the specific sound of a door closing when someone signed off. You learned to type on a keyboard, not a phone. You had a CD collection before you had an iPod. You remember when Napster changed everything, briefly, before the lawsuits shut it down.

Your childhood straddled two eras. You caught the tail end of kids playing outside until the streetlights came on, and the beginning of everyone staying inside, staring at screens. You're old enough to remember boredom—real boredom, with nothing to scroll through.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research, which is the definition that stuck after years of debate. Your generation is roughly 72 million people in the US, the largest cohort until Gen Z started surpassing you in recent years.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. You were ten. Old enough to remember exactly where you were, young enough for it to fundamentally rewire your sense of safety. The pre-9/11 world is a hazy childhood memory. Post-9/11, everything became security lines, color-coded threat levels, and the War on Terror that never seemed to end.

Your generation entered adulthood during the 2008 financial crisis. You watched the economy implode while you were in high school, then graduated into the wreckage. Jobs evaporated. Housing became unaffordable. Student loans became a life sentence. You were told to work hard and follow the rules. You did. The rules changed anyway.

Millennials are lodged between Gen X (who got careers and houses before the floor fell out) and Gen Z (who never expected the floor to exist in the first place). You're old enough to remember when the American Dream seemed possible, young enough to know it's not coming back. That combination of hope and disillusionment is your generational inheritance.

You've been blamed for killing everything from napkins to the diamond industry. You didn't kill anything—you just couldn't afford it.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Nirvana dropped 'Nevermind' and changed music forever. Kurt Cobain in a cardigan, screaming about teen spirit, became the soundtrack for a generation that wasn't yours yet but would define your childhood's ambient noise. Grunge was already fading by the time you were old enough to appreciate it.

Film in 1991 gave us 'The Silence of the Lambs,' 'Terminator 2,' and 'Beauty and the Beast.' Serial killers, killer robots, and singing teapots—the full range of human emotion. 'Terminator 2' had effects that seemed like magic then and still hold up now. 'Beauty and the Beast' was the first animated film nominated for Best Picture.

Television in 1991 launched 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' and 'Home Improvement.' You grew up on Will Smith being charming and Tim Allen grunting at power tools. Sitcoms still had laugh tracks. TV still had appointment viewing. Missing an episode meant waiting for summer reruns or accepting you'd never see it.

Your childhood was peak Nickelodeon—'Rugrats,' 'Doug,' 'The Wild Thornberrys.' Your middle school years belonged to boy bands, Britney Spears, and TRL counting down videos you'd already seen a hundred times. By high school, emo had arrived, and your MySpace profile had a Fall Out Boy song autoplaying to announce your personality.

You consumed pop culture before algorithms decided what you'd see next. You had to seek things out, wait for them, sometimes miss them entirely. Delayed gratification wasn't a choice—it was just how entertainment worked.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Tim Berners-Lee put the World Wide Web online. The internet in 1991 was a research tool for academics. Nobody predicted cat videos, social media, or the complete rewiring of human attention. You arrived just in time to watch it happen.

Linux launched in 1991, which means the operating system running most of the internet's servers is exactly your age. The PowerBook—Apple's first real laptop—debuted the same year. Portable computing was born alongside you.

You were four when Windows 95 came out. Seven when Google launched. Ten when the iPod arrived. Fourteen when Facebook opened to high schoolers. Sixteen when the iPhone dropped. You didn't grow up with smartphones—you watched them colonize the world in real time, starting in your teenage years.

This makes you one of the last generations to remember life before the internet was inescapable. You know what it's like to be unreachable. You remember using encyclopedias for homework. You can recall a time when 'going online' was an activity, not a permanent state of being.

Your relationship with technology is native but not naturalized. You learned to type on keyboards before touchscreens existed. You remember dial-up modems, AIM away messages, and burning CDs. You're fluent in digital but retain muscle memory for analog. That makes you a translator between eras—the last generation that can explain both.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born as the Soviet Union was dying. By December 1991, it was gone—the superpower that had defined global politics for seventy years dissolved before your first birthday. The Cold War was your parents' existential threat, not yours. Your anxieties would come from different sources.

The Gulf War started and ended in your first year of life. Operation Desert Storm filled television screens with green night-vision footage of bombs over Baghdad. It was the first war broadcast like a video game, and you were too young to see any of it.

The Rodney King beating was filmed in March 1991. You were weeks old. The LA riots happened the following year, when you were one. The questions those events raised—about police violence, race, and justice—would keep coming back your entire life, unchanged.

You were five when Princess Diana died in Paris. The adults around you watched her funeral on television, millions of people mourning someone most had never met. You learned early that grief could be collective, performed, and mediated through screens.

You were seven when Clinton was impeached. Ten when 9/11 happened. You remember that day clearly—the confusion, the teachers crying, being sent home early. The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq started soon after. You grew up during wartime, though the wars were far away and mostly invisible.

You were seventeen during the 2008 financial crisis. You watched your parents' retirement accounts collapse, watched foreclosure signs appear on neighbors' lawns, watched the economy that was supposed to support you crater just as you were preparing to enter it.

By twenty-four, marriage equality was the law. By twenty-six, Donald Trump was president. By twenty-nine, there was a global pandemic. You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than you can count, each one arriving before you'd recovered from the last.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated high school in 2009, directly into the worst job market since the Great Depression. College, if you went, was a four-year holding pattern while the economy theoretically recovered. It didn't, not really—not for entry-level workers, not for years.

Your generation perfected the unpaid internship, the gig economy hustle, the LinkedIn profile optimized for algorithms that might show it to someone who could help. You learned to describe yourself in corporate jargon: 'passionate,' 'self-starter,' 'results-driven.' You learned to care deeply about the mission of companies that would lay you off without warning.

You're the generation that stopped expecting loyalty from employers because employers stopped offering it first. Pensions disappeared before you entered the workforce. Raises became 'we're all in this together' speeches. Job-hopping became survival strategy, not character flaw.

You've worked in offices with beer fridges and 'unlimited PTO' policies that no one uses because using them marks you as someone who doesn't care enough. You've sat through performance reviews where you exceeded expectations and received cost-of-living adjustments that didn't match actual cost of living.

COVID normalized remote work, which proved you could do your job from anywhere. The downside: employers now expect you to be available everywhere, all the time. The boundary between work and life dissolved. You didn't work from home—you lived at work.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that watched dating become an app. Tinder launched when you were twenty-two. Swiping became the new meeting at a bar. You've probably dated someone you met online, which your parents find strange and your younger cousins find completely obvious. You're the bridge generation—old enough to remember meeting people in person, young enough to have normalized the algorithm.

You communicate primarily through text, but you remember when phone calls were normal. You know the anxiety of waiting for a response, the micro-analysis of punctuation, the different implications of 'ok' versus 'okay' versus 'OK.' You've conducted entire relationships through screens.

Your generation delayed marriage longer than any before. Not because you don't want partnership, but because weddings cost money you don't have, and houses cost more, and children cost even more than that. The life timeline your parents followed required economic conditions that no longer exist.

You've maintained long-distance friendships through group chats and video calls. You've watched relationships form and dissolve on social media. You've learned to be close to people you rarely see in person and performatively close to people you see all the time. The difference between online connection and real connection got blurry somewhere along the way.

Ghosting became a thing during your dating years. So did 'situationships' and 'talking' and every other non-committal terminology for relationships that aren't quite relationships. You've had to invent vocabulary for dynamics that previous generations didn't have to navigate.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were ten during the dot-com crash. Seventeen during the 2008 financial crisis. Twenty-nine during the COVID economic collapse. You've watched the economy implode three times before turning thirty-five. This tends to produce a financial worldview somewhere between pessimism and paranoia.

Your relationship with money is defined by scarcity that keeps getting worse. You probably have student loan debt. Housing prices have tripled since you were a teenager. The math doesn't work, and you know it, but you keep trying anyway because the alternative is giving up entirely.

You save when you can because you've seen how fast stability disappears. You invest reluctantly because you don't trust the market, but you don't trust Social Security either, so you're hedging bets on systems that might not exist when you need them. You're playing a game rigged against you because not playing means losing by default.

You've been lectured about financial responsibility by generations who bought houses for less than your annual rent. The wealth gap between Millennials and previous generations is historic. Boomers owned 21% of national wealth at your age. You own roughly 7%. The American Dream of upward mobility became a punchline in your lifetime.

Your generation is redefining what financial success means because the old definition is unattainable. Success isn't homeownership—it's affording rent in a city where the jobs are. Success isn't retiring at 65—it's having enough to stop working before your body gives out. Success isn't leaving an inheritance—it's not being a burden to your kids.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest weakness is mistaking awareness for action. You're extremely good at identifying problems—systemic racism, climate change, economic inequality. You're less good at the boring, grinding work of fixing them. Sharing an infographic isn't organizing. A hashtag isn't a movement. You sometimes confuse performance with participation.

You've gotten so used to broken systems that you've stopped questioning whether they should exist at all. You've normalized healthcare tied to employment, education requiring decades of debt, retirement as a fantasy. You've learned to cope with dysfunction instead of demanding change. Adaptability became resignation wearing a self-deprecating smile.

You're conflict-averse in ways that hurt you. You've been trained to be collaborative, to not make waves, to bring solutions instead of problems. This makes you easy to exploit. You'll work unpaid overtime for 'experience.' You'll accept equity instead of salary. You'll stay in toxic situations because leaving feels like failure.

Your irony and self-deprecation sometimes block earnestness. You can't just care about something—you have to care about it ironically, or defensively, or with seventeen layers of protective detachment. This makes it hard to advocate for yourself without undercutting the argument you're making.

You're so online that you sometimes forget offline is where the stakes are. You can mobilize millions of views on social media, but voter turnout among your generation still lags. You can cancel public figures, but changing policy requires showing up to school board meetings. The digital feels like action. It usually isn't.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2011-2021): You entered adulthood during economic recovery that never quite reached you. Entry-level jobs required experience you couldn't get without entry-level jobs. You probably lived with roommates, or parents, or both at different points. You delayed everything the previous generation did in their twenties—marriage, kids, homeownership—because the economics made those milestones impossible. Your twenties were supposed to be exploratory. They were mostly just expensive.

Your 30s (2021-2031): You're in this decade now. You're probably earning more than you did at twenty-five, but inflation ate most of the gains. You're watching younger people enter the workforce and older people retire while you're stuck in the middle, too established to start over, too financially precarious to relax. This is the decade where you're supposed to have figured things out. You haven't. Nobody has. That's the secret.

Your 40s (2031-2041): Statistically, this will be your peak earning decade. You'll have more professional authority, more clarity about what matters, more peace with what you can't change. If you have kids, they'll be getting older. Your parents will be aging, which brings responsibilities you haven't fully anticipated. You'll be managing everyone else's needs while your own get scheduled around the edges. This is the decade where you either commit to the life you've built or blow it up and rebuild from scratch.

Your 50s (2041-2051): By now, you'll have lived through at least four major economic crises, probably a couple more pandemics, and countless 'unprecedented' events that somehow keep having precedents. You'll be pre-retirement age but retirement won't be financially possible for most of your cohort. You'll mentor younger workers who don't understand why you're so cynical. You'll catch yourself sounding like the older generations you used to mock.

Your 60s and beyond (2051+): Retirement, if it exists, won't look like your grandparents' retirement. It'll be part-time work, gig economy income, or dependence on kids who are struggling themselves. Climate change will have reshaped geography. Technology will have changed in ways nobody can predict. You'll explain to younger people what life was like before the internet was everywhere, before AI was embedded in everything. They won't quite believe you.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4.1 million people born in 1991. The entire Millennial generation is about 72 million people in the US, making it the largest generation until Gen Z overtakes it sometime soon.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're more educated, more diverse, and significantly less wealthy at the same age. Gen X entered a functioning economy. You entered its wreckage. They got affordable college tuition. You got student loans that follow you for decades. They got pensions and stable employment. You got '1099 contractor' arrangements and 'unlimited PTO' that nobody uses.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is staggering. Boomers controlled 21% of national wealth when they were your age. Millennials control about 7%. Boomers bought houses for what you pay in annual rent. Boomers retired with pensions and Social Security they'll collect for decades. You're hoping those programs still exist when you're old enough to qualify.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're similar but arrived at cynicism from different directions. You remember when things seemed like they could work out. Gen Z doesn't have that memory. You believed the system was fixable. They assume it's broken and are building workarounds. You adapted to smartphones in your teens. They were born into them. You're the last generation with clear memories of before.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol-related deaths. Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before. More anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world you were promised and the world you received turned out to be very different things.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before you. You've normalized therapy, destigmatized mental health struggles, and pushed for equity in ways your parents' generation didn't. You've made the world more inclusive even as it became less affordable. That contradiction is your generational legacy.
